text: If your Xbox One controller is blinking,
try these methods to fix the issue.
To initiate the pairing process
between your controller and an Xbox,
you need to first locate the pair buttons
on the controller and the Xbox.
On the controller,

it's located on the back
next to the USB port,
and on the Xbox, it varies between models

but is usually on the front
or side and looks like this.

Now press the pair button
on your Xbox console
and release it. And within 20 seconds,
hold down the corresponding pair button
on your controller and release it.

The controller should flash
more rapidly for a moment,
then display a continuous light.
Once this happens, it's paired.
You can also pair it with your console
by connecting it via a micro USB cable.

Once plugged in, the
controller should vibrate once

to confirm the connection and
the blinking will go away.

Now when you disconnect it
from the micro USB connection,
it will also be synced wirelessly.

Another issue could be your
batteries might be dying

or are dead already and
need to be replaced.

Pop open the back and
replace the AA batteries
with a fresh set.
Your Xbox might be the problem,
and a reset could fix the issue.
You can restart your Xbox console

by holding down the power
button for 10 seconds.
Turn it back on and then try again.

One more option is updating
your controller's firmware.

This does require a
second working controller.

Plug in your blinking
controller via micro USB.
Using the working controller,
click on the Xbox button
and go to the profile and system tab.
Then settings,
then go to devices and connections,
then accessories.
Find the controller that is plugged in.
Click on the three dots.

Here, it will tell you if
an update is available.
Click it and follow the on-screen prompts
to update the firmware.
